page.title: 10NORWOOD PARK - THE HOUSE
page.content: Today, Norwood Park is a dairy farm but in 1781 it was recorded as a wood- land area with good herbage supporting a large number of deer. At that time the park was 172 acres and this stayed intact until the mid-19th Century. Originally the park was a rural retreat for the Abbots of Glastonbury and was situated at a convenient distance from the abbey for them to walk to, for privacy and sport. The house was built in the abbacy of John de Selwood in 1457. His monogram can be seen on the wall of the house. Some of the original blue lias stone building exists today but additions have been made. Features of the house include a wide wooden door through which the sacred bull could be led to be locked away at night. Near the door is a hole which could have been a leper hole.
